_exec_summary.SummaryText:
FACILITY DESCRIPTION
The Poet Biorefining-Gowrie, facility (formerly Frontier Ethanol) is located approximately 3 miles north of Gowrie, IA in Webster County.  The main product of the Poet Biorefining-Gowrie plant is denatured ethanol for use as motor vehicle fuel.  Production at the facility was initiated in May 2006.  Poet Biorefining-Gowrie produces ethanol using the dry mill method.  Corn meal is mixed with water and a digestive enzyme to produce starch, which is cooked and liquefied.  The resulting mash is cooled and a secondary enzyme is added to convert the liquefied starch to fermentable sugars.  Yeast is added to the mash to ferment the sugars to ethanol.

The fermented mash (beer) contains about 10% alcohol and is distilled, then passed through a dehydration system to produce 200-proof anhydrous ethanol.  After final dehydration, the ethanol is collected in two 1,500,000-gallon storage tanks for addition of a denaturant (natural gas condensate, NGC) to make the ethanol unfit for human consumption, per federal and state requirements.  The NGC denaturant is stored in Tank No. 805, which has a capacity of 127,000 gallons (approximately 800,000 pounds) and may also be stored occasionally in Tank 802 (270,000 gallons, approximately 1,700,000 pounds).  The denatured ethanol is shipped from the facility in tank trucks and rail cars.

CHEMICALS REGULATED UNDER EPAA?s CHEMICAL ACCIDENT PREVENTION PROGRAM
The NGC denaturant is the only CAPP/RMP regulated chemical present at Poet Biorefining-Gowrie which exceeds the CAPP quantity thresholds for applicability of the regulation.  The CAPP/RMP regulated process consists of the NGC denaturant storage tank, and the associated blending/transfer equipment and piping (since installation of in-line blending at the facility in 2010, the two 1,500,000 gallon storage tanks no longer contain denatured ethanol).  The denaturant is added to the ethanol to a concentration of 1% to 3%.  The greatest CAPP regulated quantity of denatur

ant in a tank, vessel or piping system is the maximum capacity of the denaturant storage tank (1,700,000 pounds), located in the center containment area of the tank farm.  

ACCIDENTAL RELEASE EMERGENCY RESPONSE POLICY AND PROGRAM
Poet Biorefining-Gowrie is committed to the protection of it employees, the surrounding community and the environment from hazardous substances used in the ethanol fuel production process.  In the event of an emergency, Poet Biorefining-GowrieA?s Emergency Coordinator will direct internal response activities to the extent they are within the qualifications and capabilities of company personnel, taking reasonable precautions to prevent or minimize the extent of release or the co-mingling of materials.  There is no facility emergency response team.  Employees within their designated work areas will respond to small releases, if such response does not pose a danger to their health or safety.  In the event of a larger release, it is the policy of Poet Biorefining-Gowrie to notify the Gowrie Fire Department and evacuate all employees at the facility.

ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM & CHEMICAL-SPECIFIC PREVENTION STEPS
Poet Biorefining-Gowrie is committed to protection of the environment through the combined use of inspection, maintenance, employee training and response preparation.  Public access to the facility from the highway is restricted by a gate.  Much of the property is fenced, limiting vehicle access.  The plant is fully lighted. Personnel are typically on-site 24 hours a day, 7 days a week.  There is a multi-camera video surveillance system installed at the property, and a general computer based alarm system.   The alarm system includes monitoring of the storage tanks and denaturant blending system (level control and overfill monitors).  The alarm system is monitored in the control room for abnormal conditions, which trigger visual control panel alarm lights and audible alarms.  All of the facility storage tanks have secondary

storage containment and are included in the facility Spill Prevention Control and Countermeasure (SPCC) Plan.

FIVE-YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY
The facility has an excellent record with regard to minimizing recordable and reportable accidents.  There have been no accidents since startup of the plant in May 2006 which require inclusion in the five-year accident history required by Subpart B of the CAPP/RMP regulation. 

PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY
The Poet Biorefining-Gowrie management team is committed to an on-going system of reviewing changes in available technologies and any previous plant incidents to identify opportunities to improve plant safety.  Planned changes to improve safety include a new computer based maintenance program (Maximo), which is being implemented to include automatic scheduling and work order generation for all preventative maintenance inspections and tests.
